description: Orthographic borrowing from Scots bairn, from Middle English bern, barn, from Old English bearn, from Proto-West Germanic *barn, from Proto-Germanic *barnÄ…. Doublet of barn. Compare West Frisian bern.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, and parts of Northern England) A child or baby.
examples: She moved about the country like a ghost, gathering herbs in dark loanings, lingering in kirkyairds, and casting a blight on innocent bairns.

verbs.description: bairn (third-person singular simple present bairns, present participle bairning, simple past and past participle bairned)
